title: Judges Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who came up from Gilgal to Bochim according to Judges 2:1?
options: An angel of the LORD
Joshua
A prophet
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: An angel of the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 2:1 states that an angel of the LORD came up from Gilgal to Bochim.

questions.question: What did the angel of the LORD say he would never break with Israel?
options: His covenant
His promise of wealth
His law
His commandments
questions.correctAnswer: His covenant
questions.explanation: The angel said he would never break his covenant with Israel (Judges 2:1).

questions.question: According to Judges 2:2, what were the Israelites commanded to do with the altars of the inhabitants of the land?
options: Throw them down
Offer sacrifices on them
Guard them carefully
Build new ones beside them
questions.correctAnswer: Throw them down
questions.explanation: The Israelites were told to throw down the altars of the inhabitants (Judges 2:2).

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 2:3, the LORD said He would drive out all the inhabitants from before Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 2:3 says the LORD would not drive out all the inhabitants, but they would be thorns in Israel's sides.

questions.question: What did the people do when the angel of the LORD spoke to them at Bochim?
options: They lifted up their voice and wept
They rejoiced and sang
They ignored him
They built an altar
questions.correctAnswer: They lifted up their voice and wept
questions.explanation: Judges 2:4 states that the people lifted up their voice and wept when the angel spoke.

questions.question: What name was given to the place where the Israelites sacrificed to the LORD after hearing the angel's words?
options: Bochim
Gilgal
Timnathheres
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Bochim
questions.explanation: The place was called Bochim where they sacrificed to the LORD (Judges 2:5).

questions.question: Where did each man of Israel go after Joshua let the people go?
options: Unto his inheritance to possess the land
Back to Egypt
To Gilgal
To build new altars
questions.correctAnswer: Unto his inheritance to possess the land
questions.explanation: Judges 2:6 says the children of Israel went to their inheritance to possess the land.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 2:7 says the people served the LORD only during Joshua's lifetime.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 2:7 states the people served the LORD all the days of Joshua and all the days of the elders who outlived him.

questions.question: How old was Joshua when he died according to Judges 2:8?
options: 110 years old
90 years old
120 years old
100 years old
questions.correctAnswer: 110 years old
questions.explanation: Judges 2:8 states Joshua was 110 years old when he died.

questions.question: Where was Joshua buried?
options: In the border of his inheritance in Timnathheres
In Gilgal
In Bochim
In Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: In the border of his inheritance in Timnathheres
questions.explanation: Judges 2:9 says Joshua was buried in Timnathheres, in the border of his inheritance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Judges 2:10 says that another generation arose after those who knew the LORD, which _______.
options: knew not the LORD nor the works which he had done
served the LORD faithfully
built altars to the LORD
were mighty in battle
questions.correctAnswer: knew not the LORD nor the works which he had done
questions.explanation: Judges 2:10 describes a generation that did not know the LORD or His works.

questions.question: According to Judges 2:11, what did the children of Israel do in the sight of the LORD?
options: Did evil
Did good
Built altars
Obeyed all commandments
questions.correctAnswer: Did evil
questions.explanation: Judges 2:11 states the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD.

questions.question: Who did the Israelites serve instead of the LORD according to Judges 2:13?
options: Baal and Ashtaroth
Molech and Dagon
Zeus and Apollo
No other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Baal and Ashtaroth
questions.explanation: Judges 2:13 says they forsook the LORD and served Baal and Ashtaroth.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 2:16 says the LORD raised up kings to deliver Israel from their enemies.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 2:16 says the LORD raised up judges, not kings, to deliver Israel.

questions.question: According to Judges 2:22, why did the LORD leave some nations in the land?
options: To prove Israel whether they would keep the way of the LORD
Because He loved those nations
Because Joshua asked Him to
To help Israel in battle
questions.correctAnswer: To prove Israel whether they would keep the way of the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 2:22 explains that the LORD left nations to test Israel's faithfulness.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Judges 2:1 teach us about God's faithfulness and covenant-keeping nature?
options: God will never break His covenant with His people
God only helps when we obey perfectly
God changes His promises based on our actions
God’s covenant is conditional on sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: God will never break His covenant with His people
questions.explanation: Judges 2:1 states that God said, 'I will never break my covenant with you,' demonstrating His faithfulness. This teaches us to trust God's promises even when circumstances are difficult. This is further supported by the ongoing presence of God's judges raising and delivering Israel (Judges 2:16, 18).

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with temptation to compromise their faith by forming alliances with worldly influences. Based on Judges 2:2-3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: We must avoid making agreements with worldly influences and reject their practices to stay faithful
Compromise is necessary to survive in a secular world
God allows all alliances as long as we pray
Idols help us understand other cultures better
questions.correctAnswer: We must avoid making agreements with worldly influences and reject their practices to stay faithful
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 warn Israel not to make leagues with the inhabitants or keep their altars, or else their gods will be a snare. This teaches the importance of obedience and separation from ungodly influences to maintain spiritual integrity (Judges 2:2-3, 12-13).

questions.question: What does Judges 2:4-5 teach about responding to God's correction with humility and worship?
options: Israel responded by weeping and sacrificing to the LORD at Bochim
Israel ignored the angel’s message and continued sinning
They built new altars to foreign gods as a sign of repentance
They fled the place in fear and confusion
questions.correctAnswer: Israel responded by weeping and sacrificing to the LORD at Bochim
questions.explanation: The people lifted their voices and wept after hearing the angel's message, and they called the place Bochim and sacrificed there, showing that repentance includes humility and worship (Judges 2:4-5). This is a model for believers to respond humbly when corrected.

questions.question: How does Judges 2:6-7 illustrate the importance of remembering and following God's works in family and community life?
options: The people served the LORD during Joshua’s life and the elders who witnessed God’s works
They immediately forgot God’s deeds once Joshua died
Only Joshua served the LORD, and the rest ignored Him
They relied on idols instead of God's works
questions.correctAnswer: The people served the LORD during Joshua’s life and the elders who witnessed God’s works
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 show that Israel obeyed and served the LORD as long as Joshua and the elders who saw God's mighty works lived, emphasizing the value of passing down faith and testimony through generations for family and church life.

questions.question: Based on Judges 2:8-9, how does the chapter teach us about honoring godly leadership and legacy?
options: Joshua was honored with burial in his own inheritance, marking respect for his leadership
Joshua was forgotten after death
Leaders should be buried secretly to avoid idolatry
His burial was unimportant compared to his deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua was honored with burial in his own inheritance, marking respect for his leadership
questions.explanation: Joshua’s burial in Timnathheres, his inheritance, shows respect for godly leadership and honoring those who faithfully serve God (Judges 2:8-9). This encourages Christians to value spiritual mentorship and legacy.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 2:10 indicates that a generation arose that did not know the LORD or His works, highlighting the need for intentional faith teaching within families.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 2:10 explicitly states that a new generation did not know the LORD or the works He had done, underscoring the importance of teaching faith actively to the next generation.

questions.question: How does Judges 2:11-13 warn believers about the dangers of idolatry and disobedience in personal and family life?
options: Israel did evil by serving Baalim and forsaking the LORD, provoking His anger
Idolatry was tolerated as a cultural practice
Serving other gods brought peace and prosperity
The LORD ignored their actions
questions.correctAnswer: Israel did evil by serving Baalim and forsaking the LORD, provoking His anger
questions.explanation: These verses show that turning to idols leads to forsaking God and provoking His anger, which warns believers to guard against idolatry and disobedience in all areas of life (Judges 2:11-13).

questions.question: A believer is facing consequences due to sin. Based on Judges 2:14-15, what truth can you share about God’s discipline and its purpose?
options: God’s anger results in allowing enemies to oppress us when we sin
God immediately removes all consequences regardless of sin
Suffering means God has abandoned us
Sin has no real consequences on our lives
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger results in allowing enemies to oppress us when we sin
questions.explanation: These verses explain that because of Israel’s sin, God’s anger led to their oppression by enemies, showing that discipline may come as a consequence of disobedience but is meant to bring repentance (Judges 2:14-15).

questions.question: According to Judges 2:16-18, how does God demonstrate His mercy and faithfulness even when His people repeatedly sin?
options: God raises judges to deliver Israel when they repent
God abandons Israel permanently after one sin
God ignores their cries for help
God demands perfect obedience before helping
questions.correctAnswer: God raises judges to deliver Israel when they repent
questions.explanation: Verses 16-18 show that despite Israel’s sin, God mercifully raises judges to rescue them, indicating His faithfulness and readiness to forgive when His people repent and cry out (Judges 2:16-18).

questions.question: True or False: Judges 2:17 reveals that after deliverance, Israel consistently obeyed God’s commandments and did not return to idolatry.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 2:17 indicates that Israel quickly turned away from God and went after other gods, showing the human tendency to stray and the need for perseverance in faith.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance through trials does Judges 2:19 teach us regarding repeated cycles of sin and repentance?
options: Israel’s corruption increased after each judge died, showing the need for continual spiritual vigilance
Once delivered, Israel never sinned again
Trials ended immediately after one prayer
Sin has no lasting effect on spiritual health
questions.correctAnswer: Israel’s corruption increased after each judge died, showing the need for continual spiritual vigilance
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the worsening sin after each judge’s death, teaching that believers must persevere and remain vigilant in their faith rather than becoming complacent.

questions.question: Based on Judges 2:20-22, how does God’s allowing remaining nations to live among Israel serve a spiritual purpose?
options: God left them to test Israel’s faithfulness and obedience
God forgot to remove them
They were harmless and irrelevant
God approved of their religious practices
questions.correctAnswer: God left them to test Israel’s faithfulness and obedience
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 explain that God purposely left certain nations to prove whether Israel would remain faithful and obey His ways, teaching that trials can be tests of faith and obedience.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to maintain integrity and obedience in a culture full of ungodly influences. What practical advice does Judges 2:23 provide?
options: Do not hastily follow the ways of the surrounding nations, but walk in God’s commandments
Blend in with the culture to avoid conflict
Ignore God’s commands when convenient
Accept all cultural practices as equal
questions.correctAnswer: Do not hastily follow the ways of the surrounding nations, but walk in God’s commandments
questions.explanation: Judges 2:23 shows God did not hastily drive out nations but left them to test Israel; this warns believers to avoid quickly adopting worldly ways and to remain steadfast in God’s Word.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Judges 2:7, the people served the LORD all the days of Joshua and all the days of the ________ that outlived Joshua.
options: elders
kings
priests
prophets
questions.correctAnswer: elders
questions.explanation: Judges 2:7 specifies that the people served the LORD during Joshua's life and the days of the elders who outlived him, emphasizing the role of spiritual leaders in guiding the community.

questions.question: How does Judges 2:15 encourage us to trust God’s sovereignty even when facing distress and opposition?
options: God’s hand is against us for discipline, fulfilling His word, so we should trust His plan
God abandons us in distress
Opposition means God is displeased permanently
Distress is random and unrelated to faith
questions.correctAnswer: God’s hand is against us for discipline, fulfilling His word, so we should trust His plan
questions.explanation: Verse 15 shows that distress was part of God's sovereign discipline as He had declared, teaching believers to trust God’s plan even amid trials and opposition.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Judges 2:1, the angel of the LORD reminds Israel of a covenant made. What is the significance of this covenant in the broader biblical narrative?
options: It was a promise to Abraham about the land of Canaan
It was a covenant with Moses at Mount Sinai
It was a promise made to their fathers about the land
It was a new covenant given through the judges
questions.correctAnswer: It was a promise made to their fathers about the land
questions.explanation: Judges 2:1 mentions the LORD bringing them to the land He sware unto their fathers, referring to the covenant promises made to the patriarchs such as Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob about the land of Canaan.

questions.question: According to Judges 2:2, what specific command did the LORD give to Israel concerning the inhabitants of the land?
options: Make alliances with them
Throw down their altars and make no league with them
Learn their customs and gods
Offer sacrifices together with them
questions.correctAnswer: Throw down their altars and make no league with them
questions.explanation: Judges 2:2 commands Israel not to make leagues with the inhabitants and to throw down their altars, highlighting the prohibition against syncretism and idolatry.

questions.question: What consequence did the LORD declare in Judges 2:3 due to Israel's disobedience?
options: He would bless their enemies
He would not drive out the inhabitants but let them be thorns and snares
He would send a famine upon the land
He would establish a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: He would not drive out the inhabitants but let them be thorns and snares
questions.explanation: Judges 2:3 reveals that because Israel did not obey, the LORD would not drive out the inhabitants but they would be like thorns and snares, symbolizing ongoing trouble and spiritual entrapment.

questions.question: How did the Israelites respond when the angel of the LORD spoke to them at Bochim as described in Judges 2:4?
options: They rejoiced and sang praises
They lifted up their voice and wept
They ignored the message
They attacked the angel
questions.correctAnswer: They lifted up their voice and wept
questions.explanation: Judges 2:4 states the people lifted up their voice and wept after hearing the angel's message, indicating grief and repentance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the place named 'Bochim' according to Judges 2:5?
options: It was the site of Joshua's death
It was where the Israelites first disobeyed the LORD
It was named 'Bochim' because the people wept there and offered sacrifices
It was the new capital city established by the judges
questions.correctAnswer: It was named 'Bochim' because the people wept there and offered sacrifices
questions.explanation: Judges 2:5 explains that the place was called Bochim, meaning 'weepers,' because the Israelites wept and sacrificed there in response to the angel's message.

questions.question: Judges 2:6 describes the Israelites going to their inheritances after Joshua's death. How does this reflect the fulfillment of earlier promises in the Pentateuch?
options: It shows the conquest was complete and land division was finalized
It marks the beginning of the exodus from Egypt
It indicates the building of the first temple
It signifies the establishment of a monarchy
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the conquest was complete and land division was finalized
questions.explanation: The division of land to each tribe reflects the fulfillment of the promise to Abraham and Moses concerning possession of Canaan (Num 26:52-56; Deut 1:8). Judges 2:6 shows the Israelites settling in their allotted territories.

questions.question: What contrast is drawn in Judges 2:7 between the generation of Joshua and the generation that followed?
options: The first generation was wicked, the second was righteous
The first generation served the LORD, the second did not know the LORD or His works
Both generations were equally faithful
The second generation built the temple while the first did not
questions.correctAnswer: The first generation served the LORD, the second did not know the LORD or His works
questions.explanation: Judges 2:7-10 contrasts the faithful generation that served the LORD during Joshua's time with the next generation who 'knew not the LORD, nor yet the works which he had done for Israel,' indicating spiritual decline.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 2:11-13, the children of Israel only worshipped Baal after forsaking the LORD God of their fathers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 2:13 states they served Baal and Ashtaroth, indicating worship of multiple gods, not only Baal.

questions.question: In Judges 2:14-15, what was the LORD's response to Israel's idolatry and disobedience?
options: He blessed them abundantly
He delivered them into the hands of their enemies and afflicted them
He immediately destroyed them
He sent prophets to warn them
questions.correctAnswer: He delivered them into the hands of their enemies and afflicted them
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 describe how the LORD's anger led to Israel being delivered into enemy hands and experiencing great distress, fulfilling His warnings.

questions.question: What role did the judges play according to Judges 2:16-18 in the cycle of Israel's faithfulness and disobedience?
options: They were kings who ruled Israel permanently
They delivered Israel from their enemies when the LORD raised them up
They were priests who performed sacrifices
They led Israel to build the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They delivered Israel from their enemies when the LORD raised them up
questions.explanation: Judges 2:16-18 shows that the LORD raised up judges to deliver Israel from oppressors, demonstrating God's mercy despite Israel's repeated disobedience.

questions.question: Judges 2:17 describes Israel's spiritual unfaithfulness during the judges' leadership. What literary device is used in the phrase 'went a whoring after other gods'?
options: Metaphor for idolatry
Simile comparing Israel to animals
Hyperbole to exaggerate their faithfulness
Alliteration emphasizing obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor for idolatry
questions.explanation: The phrase 'went a whoring after other gods' employs a metaphor equating Israel's idolatry with unfaithfulness and adultery, a common biblical device (see Hosea 1-3).

questions.question: How does Judges 2:20-23 explain the LORD's decision to leave certain nations in the land?
options: To punish Israel for their wickedness
To prove Israel whether they would obey the LORD or not
Because Joshua failed to destroy them
To establish peace treaties with them
questions.correctAnswer: To prove Israel whether they would obey the LORD or not
questions.explanation: Judges 2:20-23 reveals that God allowed these nations to remain as a test of Israel's faithfulness to His covenant.

questions.question: Which Old Testament concept is foreshadowed by the cycle of sin, judgment, deliverance, and relapse in Judges 2?
options: The Davidic covenant
The Mosaic covenant blessings and curses
The establishment of the temple worship
The exile to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The Mosaic covenant blessings and curses
questions.explanation: The cyclical pattern of Judges 2 reflects the covenant blessings and curses outlined in Deuteronomy 28, where obedience brings blessing and disobedience brings judgment.

questions.question: What is the historical significance of Joshua's burial place as detailed in Judges 2:9?
options: It was within the territory of Judah
It was in Timnathheres, in the hill country of Ephraim
It was in the city of Jerusalem
It was at Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: It was in Timnathheres, in the hill country of Ephraim
questions.explanation: Judges 2:9 records Joshua was buried in Timnathheres in Ephraim's hill country, marking the tribal inheritance and leadership of Ephraim among Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 2:18 indicates that the LORD's presence with the judges was contingent upon Israel's repentance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 2:18 states the LORD was with the judge and delivered Israel because He repented due to their groanings, implying divine presence was connected to Israel's repentance.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'their gods shall be a snare unto you' in Judges 2:3 connect to the broader biblical theme of idolatry?
options: It suggests idols are harmless
It foreshadows the spiritual traps of false worship seen throughout Scripture
It indicates that Israel would convert the inhabitants to Yahweh
It means the gods would protect Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the spiritual traps of false worship seen throughout Scripture
questions.explanation: Judges 2:3 uses 'snare' to symbolize how idolatry entangles and enslaves God's people, a recurring biblical theme warning against false gods.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What covenant did the angel of the LORD affirm He would never break with Israel as they entered the Promised Land?
options: The covenant made with their fathers
The covenant of circumcision
The covenant through Moses on Mount Sinai
The covenant of peace
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant made with their fathers
questions.explanation: Judges 2:1 states that the LORD brought Israel into the land He swore to their fathers and promised never to break that covenant, affirming God's faithfulness to His promises as seen also in Genesis 15:18, Exodus 6:4, Deuteronomy 7:9, and Hebrews 6:13-18.

questions.question: According to Judges 2, what were the Israelites commanded to do with the altars of the inhabitants of the land?
options: Throw down their altars
Offer sacrifices on their altars
Build new altars beside theirs
Cleanse their altars
questions.correctAnswer: Throw down their altars
questions.explanation: Judges 2:2 commands Israel to make no league with the inhabitants and to throw down their altars, illustrating God's requirement for exclusive worship, consistent with Exodus 20:3-5, Deuteronomy 12:3, 1 Kings 18:40, and 2 Corinthians 6:14-16.

questions.question: What consequence did God declare for Israel's disobedience in not driving out the inhabitants?
options: The inhabitants would be as thorns in their sides
They would lose the land immediately
They would be delivered from all enemies
They would receive immediate blessings
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants would be as thorns in their sides
questions.explanation: Judges 2:3 shows God's warning that the remaining inhabitants would be 'thorns in their sides' and their gods a snare, highlighting the consequence of spiritual compromise, paralleling Numbers 33:55, Joshua 23:13, 1 Kings 11:2-4, and Galatians 6:7-8.

questions.question: What was the emotional response of the Israelites when the angel of the LORD spoke to them at Bochim?
options: They lifted up their voice and wept
They rejoiced and sang praises
They remained silent in fear
They rebelled against the angel
questions.correctAnswer: They lifted up their voice and wept
questions.explanation: Judges 2:4 records that upon hearing the angel's words, Israel lifted their voice and wept, showing repentance and sorrow for their disobedience, consistent with 2 Chronicles 7:14, Joel 2:12-13, Psalm 51:17, and Hebrews 12:11.

questions.question: What significant event happened after Joshua's death according to Judges 2?
options: A new generation arose that did not know the LORD
Israel immediately conquered all remaining enemies
The elders continued to lead Israel faithfully
The angel of the LORD ceased to appear
questions.correctAnswer: A new generation arose that did not know the LORD
questions.explanation: Judges 2:10 highlights the rise of a generation that did not know the LORD or His works, signifying spiritual decline after Joshua's death, echoing Deuteronomy 31:20, Psalm 78:6-7, Jeremiah 2:13, and Matthew 13:13-15.

questions.question: Which gods did Israel serve that provoked the anger of the LORD according to Judges 2?
options: Baal and Ashtaroth
Molech and Dagon
Chemosh and Molech
Astarte and Dagon
questions.correctAnswer: Baal and Ashtaroth
questions.explanation: Judges 2:11-13 states Israel served Baalim and Ashtaroth, foreign gods that provoked God's wrath, consistent with 1 Kings 18:21, Jeremiah 32:35, Hosea 2:13, and Acts 7:42.

questions.question: What was God's disciplinary response to Israel's idolatry and disobedience?
options: He delivered them into the hands of their enemies
He sent prophets to rebuke them only
He immediately destroyed them
He blessed their enemies to repent
questions.correctAnswer: He delivered them into the hands of their enemies
questions.explanation: Judges 2:14-15 describes how God's anger led Him to deliver Israel into their enemies' hands as discipline, consistent with 2 Kings 17:18, Psalm 81:11-12, Isaiah 1:4, and Romans 1:24.

questions.question: Despite Israel’s repeated disobedience, what means did the LORD use to deliver them from their oppressors?
options: Raising up judges
Sending kings to lead
Calling prophets to preach
Sending angels to fight
questions.correctAnswer: Raising up judges
questions.explanation: Judges 2:16 explains that God raised judges to deliver Israel from oppressors, demonstrating His mercy and covenant faithfulness, paralleling Exodus 18:21, 1 Samuel 7:15, Psalm 89:20, and Hebrews 11:32.

questions.question: How did Israel respond to the judges raised by the LORD?
options: They did not hearken and turned to other gods
They faithfully followed the judges
They built altars for the judges
They sought to make judges kings
questions.correctAnswer: They did not hearken and turned to other gods
questions.explanation: Judges 2:17 reveals Israel's failure to listen to judges and their swift idolatry, illustrating human sinfulness and rebellion, comparable to Numbers 14:11, Judges 10:6, Jeremiah 7:24, and Romans 1:21-22.

questions.question: What was the LORD's attitude toward the judges and Israel's cries for help during oppression?
options: He was moved to compassion and delivered them
He remained silent and distant
He punished them further without relief
He sent prophets to denounce them only
questions.correctAnswer: He was moved to compassion and delivered them
questions.explanation: Judges 2:18 states that the LORD was with the judge and repented because of Israel's groanings, showing God's mercy despite Israel’s sin, consistent with Exodus 3:7, Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 63:9, and Lamentations 3:22-23.

questions.question: What happened when a judge died, according to Judges 2?
options: Israel returned to greater corruption and idolatry
Israel built a monument to the judge
Israel remained faithful to the LORD
Israel appointed a new king immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Israel returned to greater corruption and idolatry
questions.explanation: Judges 2:19 explains that after a judge died, Israel corrupted themselves more than before, highlighting the cyclical nature of sin, as seen also in Judges 21:25, 1 Samuel 8:7, Proverbs 14:34, and Romans 7:15-20.

questions.question: Why did the LORD decide not to drive out the remaining nations as He had promised?
options: To test Israel’s faithfulness to His ways
Because He had changed His mind about the land
Because Israel was too weak to fight
To punish the nations by allowing Israel to conquer them
questions.correctAnswer: To test Israel’s faithfulness to His ways
questions.explanation: Judges 2:21-22 reveals God’s purpose in leaving nations to prove Israel’s obedience, consistent with Deuteronomy 8:2, Joshua 24:14-15, Psalm 119:11, and James 1:12.

questions.question: What does Judges 2 teach about God's faithfulness and human responsibility in salvation history?
options: God remains faithful to His covenant, but humans must obey
God changes His promises based on human behavior
Human obedience is irrelevant to God's plan
God punishes without warning or opportunity for repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God remains faithful to His covenant, but humans must obey
questions.explanation: This chapter emphasizes God's unchanging covenant faithfulness (Judges 2:1, 2:21) alongside Israel's repeated disobedience (Judges 2:11-13), consistent with Numbers 23:19, Lamentations 3:22-23, Deuteronomy 30:15-20, and Hebrews 10:23-25.

questions.question: What theological theme is illustrated by Israel serving other gods and provoking the LORD to anger in Judges 2?
options: The sinfulness of idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
The acceptance of multiple gods
God’s indifference to human worship
The superiority of Baal over the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The sinfulness of idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Judges 2:11-13 exposes Israel's idolatry as a grave sin violating the covenant, consistent with Exodus 20:3-6, Deuteronomy 6:14-15, Isaiah 44:9-20, and 1 Corinthians 10:14.

questions.question: How does Judges 2 reflect the doctrine of God's holiness and justice?
options: God’s anger leads to discipline for covenant violation
God overlooks all sins without consequence
God’s justice is limited to the nations only
God is indifferent to Israel’s disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger leads to discipline for covenant violation
questions.explanation: The LORD’s hot anger and delivering Israel to enemies (Judges 2:14, 2:20) demonstrate His holiness and justice, comparable to Ezekiel 18:4, Nahum 1:2, Romans 2:5, and Hebrews 12:6.

questions.question: What messianic implication can be derived from the cycle of judges and Israel’s need for deliverance in Judges 2?
options: The need for a perfect, eternal deliverer promised in Scripture
The cycle shows that deliverance is impossible
Judges are ultimate saviors with no successor
Israel’s disobedience nullified God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: The need for a perfect, eternal deliverer promised in Scripture
questions.explanation: The recurring failures of judges point to the necessity of a Messiah who perfectly delivers, as foreshadowed in Genesis 3:15, Isaiah 9:6-7, Psalm 110:1, and Hebrews 7:23-28.
